questions.text: A 6-month-old boy begins experiencing vomiting, night sweats, and tremors after the introduction of fruit juices into his diet during weaning. Physical examination reveals significant hepatomegaly. Urine tests are positive for reducing sugars but negative for glucose. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aldolase B

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Galactokinase: Deficiency in galactokinase leads to galactosemia type 2, which primarily results in cataract formation but does not typically cause severe hypoglycemia or hepatomegaly in response to fructose ingestion.
  • • Option A. Galactokinase:
  • • Deficiency
  • • galactokinase
  • • galactosemia type 2,
  • • cataract formation
  • • does not
  • • severe hypoglycemia or hepatomegaly
  • • Option B. Fructokinase: Fructokinase deficiency leads to essential fructosuria, a benign condition characterized by the excretion of fructose in the urine without serious metabolic disturbances or clinical symptoms.
  • • Option B. Fructokinase:
  • • Fructokinase deficiency
  • • fructosuria,
  • • benign
  • • excretion of
  • • fructose
  • • urine
  • • without
  • • Option D. β-Galactosidase: Deficiency in β-galactosidase leads to GM1 gangliosidosis or galactosialidosis , which involve neurological symptoms and developmental delays , but not the specific reaction to fructose ingestion as described.
  • • Option D. β-Galactosidase:
  • • Deficiency in β-galactosidase
  • • GM1 gangliosidosis or galactosialidosis
  • • neurological symptoms
  • • developmental delays
  • • not
  • • fructose ingestion

questions.text: A research team is exploring the metabolic adaptations of cancer cells and how these cells meet their increased energy demands. In most cancer cells, the predominant metabolic pathway for generating the necessary energy is distinct from that of normal, non-cancerous cells. Which metabolic process do cancer cells primarily exploit to derive the energy needed for their rapid growth and proliferation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glycolysis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Oxidative phosphorylation : While important in many tissues, cancer cells rely less on oxidative phosphorylation compared to normal cells , partially because it is less efficient under hypoxic conditions, which are common in tumors.
  • • Option B. Oxidative phosphorylation
  • • cancer cells
  • • less
  • • oxidative phosphorylation
  • • normal cells
  • • less efficient under hypoxic conditions,
  • • common in tumors.
  • • Option C. TCA cycle in mitochondria : The TCA cycle is used by all cells , but cancer cells often have mitochondrial defects that reduce their reliance on this pathway.
  • • Option C. TCA cycle in mitochondria
  • • TCA cycle
  • • all cells
  • • cancer cells
  • • mitochondrial defects
  • • reduce
  • • reliance
  • • pathway.
  • • Option D. Beta-oxidation : This pathway oxidizes fatty acids to generate acetyl-CoA for energy ; however, cancer cells typically rely on this less than on glycolysis.
  • • Option D. Beta-oxidation
  • • oxidizes fatty acids
  • • acetyl-CoA for energy
  • • cancer cells
  • • rely on
  • • less
  • • glycolysis.

This metabolic adaptation allows cancer cells to thrive even under hypoxic conditions and contributes to the acidic microenvironment often seen in tumors due to lactate production.

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Glucose from diet > gluconeogenesis > glycogenolysis: This sequence is incorrect because glycogenolysis typically precede s gluconeogenesis in the fasting state as the body utilizes stored glycogen before synthesizing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources.

questions.text: A medical student is reviewing the glycolytic pathway and is attempting to identify the points of regulation within the process. She notes that certain steps are irreversible and thus play a key role in the regulation of glycolysis. Which of the following enzymes catalyzes a reaction in glycolysis that is not considered irreversible and therefore not a major regulatory point?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Enolase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B. Phosphofructokinase : Catalyzes an irreversible step by converting fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate and is a major regulatory point of glycolysis.
  • • Option B. Phosphofructokinase
  • • Option C. Pyruvate Kinase : Irreversibly Catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate, another regulatory step in glycolysis.
  • • Option C. Pyruvate Kinase
  • • Option D. Hexokinase : Irreversibly phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate at the start of the glycolytic pathway and is allosterically inhibited by its product, making it a key regulatory enzyme.
  • • Option D. Hexokinase

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with fatigue, abdominal pain, and hepatomegaly, with abnormal liver function tests suggesting ethanol toxicity. What could be the underlying biochemical change associated with ethanol toxicity in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Increased NADH/NAD+ ratio

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Decreased lactate/pyruvate ratio: Ethanol metabolism actually leads to an increased lactate/pyruvate ratio due to the conversion of pyruvate to lactate in the presence of excess NADH.
  • • Option A. Decreased lactate/pyruvate ratio:
  • • Ethanol
  • • increased lactate/pyruvate ratio
  • • pyruvate to lactate
  • • NADH.
  • • Option C. Stimulation of gluconeogenesis: Ethanol metabolism inhibits gluconeogenesis due to the increased NADH/NAD+ ratio and the subsequent diversion of substrates like pyruvate and oxaloacetate to lactate and malate , respectively.
  • • Option C. Stimulation of gluconeogenesis: Ethanol
  • • inhibits gluconeogenesis
  • • increased NADH/NAD+ ratio
  • • diversion
  • • pyruvate and oxaloacetate
  • • lactate and malate
  • • Option D. Stimulation of fatty acid oxidation: Ethanol metabolism inhibits fatty acid oxidation , again due to the increased NADH/NAD+ ratio. Instead, there is an accumulation of fatty acids leading to fatty liver.
  • • Option D. Stimulation of fatty acid oxidation:
  • • Ethanol
  • • inhibits fatty acid oxidation
  • • increased
  • • NADH/NAD+ ratio.
  • • accumulation of fatty acids
  • • fatty liver.

His parents note his recent high protein intake, attributed to his athletic activities. Hyperammonemia can disrupt the TCA cycle by depleting a specific intermediate, leading to impaired energy metabolism. Which TCA cycle intermediate is most likely depleted in this scenario, contributing to the cycle's inhibition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) α-ketoglutarate

Educational Objective:

Ammonia is detoxified in the liver by the urea cycle, which consumes α-ketoglutarate as it combines with ammonia to form glutamate. This process depletes α-ketoglutarate , a critical intermediate in the TCA cycle , leading to impaired energy metabolism and contributing to the symptoms observed.

questions.text: Assertion (A): Piericidin and rotenone are inhibitors of (ETC) electron transport chain. Reasoning ®: Piericidin and rotenone inhibits the flow of electron between the complex II and ubiquinone (coenzyme Q)

options.label: A
options.text: A and R both are right but R is not the Correct explanation of A

options.label: B
options.text: A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A

options.label: C
options.text: A and R both are wrong

options.label: D
options.text: A is true but R is false

questions.correct_answer: D. A is true but R is false
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) A is right statement but R is not a correct explanation of statement A.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Piericidin and rotenone are indeed inhibitors of the electron transport chain (ETC), specifically affecting the function of Complex I ( NADH dehydrogenase ). They block the transfer of electrons from NADH to ubiquinone ( coenzyme Q ), no t from Complex II . This action inhibits the electron transport chain early in its sequence, preventing the establishment of the proton gradient necessary for ATP synthesis via oxidative phosphorylation . The assertion is correct in stating that these compounds are inhibitors of the ETC , but the reasoning is incorrect as it misidentifies the site of inhibition .

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • GLUT4 is the major glucose transporter seen in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue . GLUT4 is under the control of insulin . Insulin promotes the translocation of intracellular GLUT4 molecules to the cell surface and thus increases glucose uptake. In Type 2 diabetes mellitus , membrane GLUT4 is reduced causing insulin resistance in muscle and fat cells. In diabetes, entry of glucose into muscle is only half of normal cells.

questions.text: A 42-year-old visits a local clinic for a routine check-up. The healthcare provider at the clinic performs an Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) to assess his glucose metabolism. The results are plotted on a graph showing plasma glucose levels over time after a glucose load. Based on the graph shown, what is your interpretation of the patient’s OGTT results?

options.label: A
options.text: Symptoms of Diabetes mellitus with inconclusive blood glucose values

options.label: D
options.text: Follow-up of a case of Diabetes mellitus

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Based on the graph provided, which shows plasma glucose levels after a glucose load:
  • • The normal curve rises to about 140 mg/dL and then returns to baseline (~90 mg/dL) within 2 hours. The diabetic curve spikes up to ~300 mg/dL at 1 hour and remains significantly elevated (well above 200 mg/dL) even at 2 hours. the Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) is interpreted as follows: Normal: Fasting glucose < 100 mg/dL; 2-hour post-load < 140 mg/dL. Impaired glucose tolerance: fasting glucose 100-126 mg/dl; 2-hour post-load 140–199 mg/dL. Diabetes mellitus: Fasting ≥ 126 mg/dL or 2-hour post-load ≥ 200 mg/dL .
  • • The normal curve rises to about 140 mg/dL and then returns to baseline (~90 mg/dL) within 2 hours.
  • • The diabetic curve spikes up to ~300 mg/dL at 1 hour and remains significantly elevated (well above 200 mg/dL) even at 2 hours.
  • • the Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) is interpreted as follows:
  • • Normal: Fasting glucose < 100 mg/dL; 2-hour post-load < 140 mg/dL.
  • • Impaired glucose tolerance: fasting glucose 100-126 mg/dl; 2-hour post-load 140–199 mg/dL.
  • • Diabetes mellitus: Fasting ≥ 126 mg/dL or 2-hour post-load ≥ 200 mg/dL .
  • • Interpretation :
  • • Interpretation
  • • The patient's OGTT pattern on the graph matches the diabetic curve (persistent elevation above 200 mg/dL even after 2 hours), clearly meeting criteria for overt diabetes mellitus.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Symptoms of Diabetes mellitus with inconclusive blood glucose values : This applies when symptoms are present but glucose levels don’t conclusively meet diagnostic thresholds (not the case here, where the glucose is clearly high). Option C. Diabetic nephropathy : This is a complication of diabetes involving kidney damage and is not diagnosed by OGTT . OGTT assesses glucose metabolism, not kidney function. Option D. Follow-up of a case of Diabetes mellitus : OGTT is not recommended for follow-up of known diabetes cases. HbA1c, fasting glucose, and self-monitoring of blood glucose are the preferred methods for monitoring glycemic control in diagnosed patients.
  • • Option A. Symptoms of Diabetes mellitus with inconclusive blood glucose values : This applies when symptoms are present but glucose levels don’t conclusively meet diagnostic thresholds (not the case here, where the glucose is clearly high).
  • • Option A. Symptoms of Diabetes mellitus with inconclusive blood glucose values
  • • Option C. Diabetic nephropathy : This is a complication of diabetes involving kidney damage and is not diagnosed by OGTT . OGTT assesses glucose metabolism, not kidney function.

  • • Option D. Follow-up of a case of Diabetes mellitus : OGTT is not recommended for follow-up of known diabetes cases. HbA1c, fasting glucose, and self-monitoring of blood glucose are the preferred methods for monitoring glycemic control in diagnosed patients.
  • • Option D. Follow-up of a case of Diabetes mellitus

HSL is activated by phosphorylation in response to low insulin and high glucagon levels , which are typical during fasting . Thus, in a fasting state , HSL would be phosphorylated and active to facilitate the mobilization of fat stores .

questions.text: An Infant diagnosed with Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI) presents with vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and hypoglycemia upon attempting weaning. Following a positive IV fructose tolerance test, dietary restriction of fructose is advised. Considering the metabolic pathway affected in HFI, which of the following substances should be restricted in the neonate's diet?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sucrose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Infants with Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI), dietary restriction of sucrose is crucial due to its breakdown into glucose and fructose, the latter of which cannot be metabolized due to aldolase B deficiency, leading to toxic metabolite buildup and hypoglycemia. Other sugars like galactose, glucose, and lactose, which do not directly contribute to these metabolic issues, do not need to be restricted unless other specific metabolic disorders are present.

questions.text: A 39-year-old female presents with weight loss, fatigue, nocturia, and excessive thirst. Laboratory findings reveal fasting blood sugar (FBS) >140 mg/dl and postprandial blood sugar (PPBS) >250 mg/dl, leading to a probable diagnosis of Type 1 diabetes mellitus. Considering the pathophysiology of Type 1 diabetes mellitus, which of the following statements is TRUE?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increased lipolysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type 1 diabetes mellitus is characterized by an autoimmune destruction of pancreatic β-cells , leading to absolute insulin deficiency . Insulin normally inhibits lipolysis , so its deficiency in Type 1 diabetes results in increased lipolysis in adipose tissue . This leads to elevated levels of free fatty acids in the bloodstream, which can contribute to the production of ketone bodies in the liver, a common complication in uncontrolled diabetes.

  • ➤ free fatty acids

  • ➤ common complication
  • ➤ uncontrolled diabetes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with Type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with a blood glucose level greater than 300 mg/dl. In the context of his elevated blood glucose, which of the following metabolic processes continues to occur normally in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Increased conversion of fatty acid to Acetyl CoA

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased conversion of fatty acid to Acetyl CoA
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Increased conversion of fatty acid to Acetyl CoA

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In Type 1 diabetes mellitus with significantly elevated blood glucose (>300 mg/dl), insulin deficiency leads to dramatic metabolic alterations. Without insulin, glucose uptake by peripheral tissues is impaired, leading to hyperglycemia. Simultaneously, the body shifts to alternative fuel sources:
  • • Increased fatty acid mobilization from adipose tissue occurs in insulin deficiency. These fatty acids undergo β-oxidation in the liver, resulting in increased conversion to Acetyl CoA.
  • • The excess Acetyl CoA cannot enter the TCA cycle efficiently due to low oxaloacetate availability (diverted to gluconeogenesis), and instead is shunted toward ketogenesis, producing ketone bodies (acetoacetate, β-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone). This leads to diabetic ketoacidosis in uncontrolled Type 1 diabetes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Increased protein synthesis : Insulin promotes protein synthesis and inhibits protein breakdown. In Type 1 diabetes with insulin deficiency, protein synthesis decreases while proteolysis increases, providing amino acids for gluconeogenesis. This contributes to the catabolic state and muscle wasting seen in poorly controlled diabetes.
  • • Option A. Increased protein synthesis
  • • Option B. Glycogenesis in muscle : This process requires both insulin and adequate glucose transport into muscle cells via GLUT4 transporters. Insulin deficiency impairs GLUT4 translocation to the cell membrane, reducing glucose uptake and subsequent glycogen synthesis in muscle tissue.
  • • Option B. Glycogenesis in muscle
  • • Option D. Decreased triglyceride level - This is incorrect. In Type 1 diabetes with insulin deficiency, triglyceride levels are not decreased but are typically increased due to impaired clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins due to decreased lipoprotein lipase activity (an insulin-dependent enzyme) This often leads to hypertriglyceridemia, not decreased triglyceride levels.
  • • Option D. Decreased triglyceride level

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In uncontrolled Type 1 diabetes with hyperglycemia, insulin deficiency creates a catabolic state where fat mobilization and fatty acid oxidation are accelerated, leading to increased Acetyl CoA production and ketogenesis. This represents a shift from glucose to fat metabolism. Meanwhile, anabolic processes like protein synthesis and glycogenesis are impaired, highlighting the crucial role of insulin in regulating metabolic pathways.
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: p 149, Lippincott: P 340
  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: A patient with a known history of diabetes mellitus presents to the outpatient department for a routine follow-up appointment after three months. As part of the management and monitoring plan, the healthcare provider requests an HbA1c test, which is crucial for assessing long-term glycemic control. Considering the various methods available for HbA1c estimation, which of the following is considered the most accurate and reliable method?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) High performance liquid chromatography

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Affinity chromatography: While affinity chromatography can be used for HbA1c measurement, it is not as specific or as widely used as HPLC. It relies on the specific binding of HbA1c to a particular substrate, which can be influenced by the presence of hemoglobin variants.

  • • hemoglobin variants.
  • • Option B. Electrophoresis: Electrophoresis can separate different hemoglobin types based on their electric charge, but it is less precise than HPLC for quantifying HbA1c levels and can be affected by the presence of hemoglobin variants.
  • • Option B. Electrophoresis:
  • • different hemoglobin types
  • • electric charge,
  • • less
  • • HPLC for quantifying HbA1c levels
  • • affected
  • • presence of hemoglobin variants.
  • • Option D. Isoelectric focusing: This technique separates proteins based on their isoelectric points. While it can differentiate various hemoglobin forms , it is not the preferred method for routine HbA1c estimation due to its complexity and the difficulty in quantification.
  • • Option D. Isoelectric focusing:
  • • proteins based
  • • isoelectric
  • • hemoglobin forms

  • • routine HbA1c estimation
  • • its complexity
  • • difficulty
  • • quantification.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is widely recognized as the gold standard for HbA1c estimation due to its accuracy, reliability, and reproducibility . HPLC separates various forms of hemoglobin, including HbA1c, based on their charge and size under high pressure , allowing for precise quantification. This method minimizes interference from hemoglobin variants and provides a clear, specific measurement of HbA1c levels , which reflect the average blood glucose concentration over the previous 2-3 months.

questions.text: A genetic counselor is discussing the potential impact of enzyme deficiencies on metabolic pathways with a couple awaiting the birth of their child. The counselor explains that certain genetic conditions can disrupt normal metabolic processes. She asks the couple to consider the statement: "A defect in the pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex can lead to lactic acidosis." Is this statement true or false?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) True

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A PDH defect can indeed lead to lactic acidosis. The PDH complex is responsible for converting pyruvate to acetyl CoA, a step that links glycolysis to the citric acid cycle . If PDH is deficient or defective , pyruvate cannot effectively enter the citric acid cycle and is instead converted to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase. This can lead to an accumulation of lactate in the blood, resulting in lactic acidosis.

questions.text: The assertion and reasoning provided require analysis to understand the action of atractyloside and its effects on mitochondrial function. Assertion (A): Atractyloside prevents ATP synthesis in the matrix of mitochondria. Reasoning (R): Atractyloside blocks complex V, the F0 component of inner mitochondrial membrane and stops the inflow of H+ into the matrix.

questions.correct_answer: B. A is right but R is a wrong statement

Ans. B) A is right but R is a wrong statement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Atractyloside is known to inhibit ATP synthesis, but not by blocking complex V (ATP synthase) or the F0 component. Instead, atractyloside inhibits the ADP/ATP carrier (also known as the adenine nucleotide translocase ) in the inner mitochondrial membrane , which is responsible for exchanging ADP and ATP between the mitochondrial matrix and the cytosol . This inhibition prevents the export of ATP from the mitochondria to the cytosol and the import of ADP from the cytosol to the matrix, thus inhibiting ATP synthesis indirectly.

questions.text: In the past, the uncoupler 2,4-dinitrophenol was used as a weight- reducing drug until side effects such as fatigue and breathlessness precluded its use. How could the use of this drug result in weight loss?

options.label: B
options.text: 2,4-dinitrophenol inhibits transport of pyruvate into the mitochondria. Fats are therefore metabolized to glycerol and subsequently to pyruvate, depleting fat stores.

options.label: C
options.text: 2,4-dinitrophenol allows oxidation of fats in adipose tissue without production of ATP. Fat oxidation can thus proceed continuously and fat stores will be used up.

options.label: D
options.text: 2,4-dinitrophenol causes ATP to be produced at a higher rate than normal, thus causing weight loss.

questions.correct_answer: C. 2,4-dinitrophenol allows oxidation of fats in adipose tissue without production of ATP. Fat oxidation can thus proceed continuously and fat stores will be used up.

questions.text: Cytochrome c, typically associated with the electron transport chain, also plays a role in mediating apoptosis. Is this statement true or false?.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) True

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cytochrome c indeed mediates apoptosis. Upon release from the mitochondria into the cytosol in response to apoptotic stimuli, cytochrome c interacts with Apaf-1 (apoptotic protease activating factor-1) and procaspase-9 to form the apoptosome . questions.text: Among the following options, which one does NOT act as an uncoupler of oxidative phosphorylation?
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oligomycin is an antibiotic which inhibits flow of protons through Fo by binding complex V. It is not an uncoupler. Ionophores are lipid-soluble compounds which increases the permeability of lipid bilayers to certain ions. There are two types of ionophores : mobile ion carries (e.g. valinomycin ) and channel formers (e.g. gramicidin). Valinomycin allows potassium to permeate mitochondria and dissipate the proton gradient. 2,4-dinitrophenol is a protonophore and acts as a synthetic uncoupler. Thermogenin is a mitochondrial membrane protein naturally present in brown adipose tissues and acts as an uncoupler. All of these inhibit oxidative phosphorylation by dissipating proton gradient.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department by their parents due to concerns of muscle hypotonia, failure to thrive, and an enlarged abdomen. Laboratory tests reveal hypoglycemia and ultrasonography shows hepatomegaly. Following a comprehensive evaluation, the child is diagnosed with a type of glycogen storage disease (GSD). In the context of GSD, the glycogen content in the liver is not influenced by which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Dietary riboflavin (vitamin B2) levels do not directly influence glycogen content in the liver in the context of glycogen storage diseases (GSDs).
  • • Riboflavin serves as a precursor for flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), which function as cofactors for various oxidation-reduction enzymes. While riboflavin is essential for many metabolic processes, it does not play a direct regulatory role in glycogen synthesis or breakdown in the liver.
  • • Glycogen storage diseases are inherited metabolic disorders caused by enzyme deficiencies in glycogen synthesis, breakdown, or regulation pathways. The clinical presentation described in the question (muscle hypotonia, failure to thrive, enlarged abdomen, hypoglycemia, and hepatomegaly) is consistent with several types of GSD.
  • • The regulation of hepatic glycogen content primarily depends on hormonal and metabolic factors that directly control glycogen synthesis (glycogenesis) and breakdown (glycogenolysis).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Serum glucose levels - This is incorrect as a choice for factors that do NOT influence glycogen content.
  • • Option A. Serum glucose levels
  • • Serum glucose levels directly affect hepatic glycogen metabolism. High blood glucose promotes glycogen synthesis through activation of glycogen synthase, while low blood glucose levels trigger glycogen breakdown to maintain normoglycemia.
  • • Option B. Insulin levels - This is incorrect as a choice for factors that do NOT influence glycogen content. Insulin is a key hormone that promotes glycogen synthesis in the liver by:
  • • Option B. Insulin levels
  • • Activating glycogen synthase (via dephosphorylation) Inhibiting glycogen phosphorylase Increasing glucose uptake and its phosphorylation to glucose-6-phosphate
  • • Activating glycogen synthase (via dephosphorylation)
  • • Inhibiting glycogen phosphorylase
  • • Increasing glucose uptake and its phosphorylation to glucose-6-phosphate
  • • Option C. Glucagon Level - This is incorrect as a choice for factors that do NOT influence glycogen content. Glucagon has effects opposite to insulin on hepatic glycogen. It promotes glycogenolysis (glycogen breakdown) by:
  • • Option C. Glucagon Level
  • • Activating glycogen phosphorylase via a cAMP-dependent protein kinase cascade Inhibiting glycogen synthase
  • • Activating glycogen phosphorylase via a cAMP-dependent protein kinase cascade
  • • Inhibiting glycogen synthase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ In glycogen storage diseases, liver glycogen content is regulated primarily by glucose levels, insulin, Glucagon and factors affecting these parameters (like dietary amino acids).

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe polyuria and polydipsia. Laboratory tests reveal the presence of ketones in her urine. Considering the metabolic conditions, which is the most likely source of these ketones?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Free fatty acid breakdown

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ketone bodies are produced primarily in the live r through the process of ketogenesis, which occurs when there is an increased breakdown of free fatty acids . This situation typically arises in states of decreased carbohydrate availability or impaired glucose utilization, leading the body to switch to fat as an alternative energy source . In this patient's case, the presence of ketones in the urine suggests that her body is utilizing fatty acids for energy, which results in the production of ketones as a byproduct of fatty acid metabolism in the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the specialized mammalian tissue/organ where fuel oxidation is primarily used to generate heat rather than produce ATP?

options.label: A
options.text: It is concerned with energy storage

options.label: B
options.text: Non-shivering thermogenesis is a hormonal stimulus

options.label: C
options.text: It is primarily important in adults

options.label: D
options.text: It liberates heat by coupling oxidation from phosphorylation

questions.correct_answer: B. Non-shivering thermogenesis is a hormonal stimulus
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Non-shivering thermogenesis is a hormonal stimulus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. It is concerned with energy storage: This statement is more applicable to white adipose tissue , which is the body's main form of energy storage. Brown adipose tissue , on the other hand, is specialized for energy expenditure in the form of heat .

  • • white adipose tissue

  • • energy expenditure
  • • heat
  • • Option C. It is primarily important in adults: Brown adipose tissue is most prominent and active in infants , where it plays a critical role in thermogenesis to maintain body temperature . Its prevalence and activity typically decrease with age .

  • • Brown adipose tissue
  • • prominent and active in infants
  • • thermogenesis
  • • body temperature
  • • prevalence and activity
  • • decrease with age
  • • Option D. It liberates heat by coupling oxidation from phosphorylation: The correct mechanism in brown adipose tissue involves the uncoupling of oxidation from phosphorylation , not coupling , which allows the energy from fuel oxidation to be released as heat instead of being used to produce ATP.
  • • Option D. It liberates heat by coupling oxidation from phosphorylation:
  • • correct
  • • brown adipose tissue
  • • uncoupling of oxidation
  • • phosphorylation
  • • not coupling
  • • energy from fuel oxidation
  • • released as heat

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brown adipose tissue (BAT) is primarily involved in non-shivering thermogenesis, a process of heat production in mammals . This process is stimulated hormonally, particularly by norepinephrine , which is released in response to cold exposure. BAT contains a high number of mitochondria with uncoupling protein 1 (UCP1), which allows the uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation; instead of producing ATP , the energy is released as heat .

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was brought to the hospital in a disoriented, confused state by her husband. She is a known case of type 1 diabetes for the last 25 years. O/E –she had signs of dehydration, Low BP and acidosis with faintly fruity odour. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Diabetic ketoacidosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B. Uncontrolled diabetes : While the patient does have diabetes, the specific presentation with acidosis, ketonemia, and the clinical context suggest DKA rather than just uncontrolled diabetes.
  • • Option B. Uncontrolled diabetes
  • • Option C. Lactic acidosis : Lactic acidosis presents with acidosis but is typically associated with severe hypoperfusion or hypoxia, and the ketone levels would not be elevated as they are in this case.
  • • Option C. Lactic acidosis
  • • Option D. Diabetes insipidus : Diabetes insipidus is characterized by polyuria and polydipsia due to a deficiency of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) or kidney's response to ADH, but it does not cause hyperglycemia, acidosis, or ketonemia.
  • • Option D. Diabetes insipidus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diabetic ketoacidosis is an acute, potentially life-threatening complication of diabetes characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. Clinical presentation typically includes dehydration, Kussmaul breathing, fruity breath odor (acetone), altered mental status, and hypotension.

questions.text: A middle aged known alcoholic was found lying semiconscious at his residence and was taken to ER. Laboratory studies showed a large anion gap, elevated blood alcohol levels - 245 mg/dL and low blood glucose - 38 mg/dL. The patient’s large anion gap and hypoglycemia can be explained by which of the following?

Ans. C)  Inhibition of dehydrogenase enzymes by NADH

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Decreased secretion of glucagon: While glucagon secretion may be affected in chronic alcoholics due to pancreatic damage , it is not the primary cause of the large anion gap or hypoglycemia in acute ethanol intoxication.

  • • Option B. Increased secretion of insulin: Acute ethanol ingestion typically does not cause an increase in insulin secretion. In fact, hypoglycemia in this context is more related to the inhibition of gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis rather than insulin-mediated glucose uptake.

  • • Acute ethanol ingestion
  • • does not
  • • increase in insulin secretion.
  • • hypoglycemia
  • • more
  • • inhibition of gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis
  • • Option D. Inhibition of glycogenolysis by ethanol: While ethanol can impair glycogenolysis, the more significant impact on the anion gap and hypoglycaemia is through the inhibition of dehydrogenase enzymes by the increased NADH/NAD+ ratio, affecting gluconeogenesis and leading to the accumulation of organic acids.

  • • gluconeogenesis

The metabolic stress in them leads to the increase in secretion of epinephrine and other hormones → mobilize fatty acids from stored triglycerides in adipose cells → undergo beta-oxidation → get converted to ketone bodies because of the inhibition of the TCA cycle by high levels of NADH (produced by the oxidation of ethanol first to acetaldehyde and acetate). Key gluconeogenic dehydrogenases are also inhibited by the elevated levels of NADH, including lactate dehydrogenase, glycerol 3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and malate dehydrogenase.

questions.text: A young woman with laboratory picture of normocytic anaemia and jaundice with splenomegaly was diagnosed to have RBC pyruvate kinase deficiency after a PBS showed spiculated cells. Due to the abnormal function of pyruvate kinase, less pyruvate is formed and the intermediates above pyruvate in the glycolytic pathway get accumulated. Which of the following products is not formed in appropriate amounts in the RBC due to the deficiency of pyruvate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lactate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This question tests understanding of RBC metabolism, particularly the consequences of pyruvate kinase deficiency. Pyruvate kinase deficiency is an inherited disorder that affects glycolysis in RBCs, leading to premature destruction of red blood cells (hemolytic anemia). The spiculated RBCs seen on peripheral blood smear are characteristic of this condition. The defect causes ATP depletion, accumulation of glycolytic intermediates upstream of the enzyme defect, and reduced production of downstream metabolites like lactate.
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: p 170; Vasudevan 9/e: 111.
  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: Can the acetyl CoA, derived from fatty acid oxidation, be converted back into glucose to maintain blood glucose levels? What is the correct response based on human metabolic pathways?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) False

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Acetyl CoA cannot be converted into glucose in humans because the reactions of the citric acid cycle are not reversible , and there is no pathway that can convert acetyl CoA back to pyruvate or any other gluconeogenic precursors. This underscores the importance of the concept that while glucose can be converted into acetyl CoA, the reverse is not true , marking a one-way route towards energy production.

questions.text: Which of the following options correctly represents the diagnostic criteria for Diabetes Mellitus?

options.label: A
options.text: If the fasting plasma sugar is more than 126 mg /dl, on more than one occasion

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: If the random plasma sugar level is more than 200 mg/dl, on more than one occasion.

  • • Option B. 2-hour post-glucose load value of GTT more than 200 mg/dl: This too is a valid criterion for diagnosing diabetes, even if observed on just one occasion, provided there are classic symptoms of hyperglycemia.
  • • Option B. 2-hour post-glucose load value of GTT more than 200 mg/dl:
  • • Option C. Random plasma sugar level more than 200 mg/dl, on more than one occasion: While a single measurement with classic symptoms can be sufficient, additional confirmation enhances the diagnostic certainty, especially in asymptomatic individuals.

questions.text: During a review of laboratory practices, a medical student is presented with a case study. A 55-year-old woman underwent routine blood work at 8 am in plain Vacutainer, but her blood glucose level was not processed until 11 am, with results reported at noon showing a blood glucose level of 48 mg/dl, despite all other tests being normal. Sample for blood glucose should be taken in Vacutainer containing NaF because it inhibit the following enzyme:
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This question highlights the importance of proper pre-analytical handling of blood samples for glucose testing. Blood samples should either be processed immediately or collected in tubes containing glycolysis inhibitors (such as sodium fluoride) to prevent falsely lowered glucose results due to continued cellular metabolism. The case demonstrates how delayed processing can lead to clinically significant errors in laboratory results, potentially misleading diagnosis and treatment decisions.
  • ➤ Ref : Vasudevan 9/e: 111.
  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: During the conversion of α-ketoglutarate to succinate in the TCA cycle, several reactions occur, leading to the production of energy-rich molecules. This conversion involves the decarboxylation of α-ketoglutarate, the generation of Succinyl CoA, and the subsequent formation of succinate. how many ATP molecules are typically produced through this series of reactions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 3.5

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The conversion of α-ketoglutarate to succinate in the TCA cycle involves two key steps:
  • • First, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of α-ketoglutarate to form succinyl-CoA, CO₂, and NADH. The NADH produced in this step will yield approximately 2.5 ATP molecules when oxidized through the electron transport chain. Second, succinyl-CoA synthetase (also called succinate thiokinase) catalyzes the conversion of succinyl-CoA to succinate with the generation of GTP (which is energetically equivalent to ATP. This substrate-level phosphorylation directly produces 1 GTP/ATP molecule.
  • • First, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of α-ketoglutarate to form succinyl-CoA, CO₂, and NADH. The NADH produced in this step will yield approximately 2.5 ATP molecules when oxidized through the electron transport chain.
  • • The NADH produced in this step will yield approximately 2.5 ATP molecules when oxidized through the electron transport chain.
  • • The NADH produced in this step will yield approximately 2.5 ATP molecules when oxidized through the electron transport chain.
  • • Second, succinyl-CoA synthetase (also called succinate thiokinase) catalyzes the conversion of succinyl-CoA to succinate with the generation of GTP (which is energetically equivalent to ATP. This substrate-level phosphorylation directly produces 1 GTP/ATP molecule.
  • • This substrate-level phosphorylation directly produces 1 GTP/ATP molecule.
  • • This substrate-level phosphorylation directly produces 1 GTP/ATP molecule.
  • • Therefore, the total ATP yield from converting α-ketoglutarate to succinate is:
  • • 2.5 ATP from NADH oxidation in the electron transport chain 1 ATP from substrate-level phosphorylation (GTP formation) Total: 3.5 ATP molecules
  • • 2.5 ATP from NADH oxidation in the electron transport chain
  • • 1 ATP from substrate-level phosphorylation (GTP formation)
  • • Total: 3.5 ATP molecules
  • • This makes option C (3.5) the correct answer.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the energetics of the TCA cycle reactions, specifically:
  • ➤ The α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex reaction produces NADH The succinyl-CoA synthetase reaction produces GTP/ATP via substrate-level phosphorylation NADH yields approximately 2.5 ATP when oxidized through the electron transport chain Together, these reactions yield 3.5 ATP molecules from the conversion of α-ketoglutarate to succinate
  • ➤ The α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex reaction produces NADH
  • ➤ The succinyl-CoA synthetase reaction produces GTP/ATP via substrate-level phosphorylation
  • ➤ NADH yields approximately 2.5 ATP when oxidized through the electron transport chain
  • ➤ Together, these reactions yield 3.5 ATP molecules from the conversion of α-ketoglutarate to succinate

questions.text: Among the following, which is NOT a function or significance of the TCA cycle?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The synthesis of NADPH is NOT a function of the TCA cycle. The TCA cycle (tricarboxylic acid cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle or citric acid cycle) produces NADH, not NADPH. This is a key distinction because NADH and NADPH have different roles in metabolism:
  • • NADH primarily serves as an electron carrier for energy production in the electron transport chain NADPH serves as a reducing agent for biosynthetic reactions and antioxidant defense
  • • NADH primarily serves as an electron carrier for energy production in the electron transport chain
  • • NADPH serves as a reducing agent for biosynthetic reactions and antioxidant defense
  • • The TCA cycle specifically generates reduced electron carriers in the form of NADH (three molecules per acetyl-CoA) and FADH₂ (one molecule per acetyl-CoA), but not NADPH. NADPH is primarily produced by other pathways such as:
  • • The pentose phosphate pathway The malic enzyme reaction Isocitrate dehydrogenase in the cytosol (not the mitochondrial form involved in the TCA cycle) NADP⁺-dependent glutamate dehydrogenase NADP⁺-dependent malate dehydrogenase (malic enzyme)
  • • The pentose phosphate pathway
  • • The malic enzyme reaction
  • • Isocitrate dehydrogenase in the cytosol (not the mitochondrial form involved in the TCA cycle)
  • • NADP⁺-dependent glutamate dehydrogenase
  • • NADP⁺-dependent malate dehydrogenase (malic enzyme)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Complete oxidation of acetyl CoA - This IS a function of the TCA cycle. The cycle completely oxidizes the two-carbon acetyl group of acetyl-CoA to two molecules of CO₂. This oxidation is coupled with the reduction of electron carriers (NAD⁺ to NADH and FAD to FADH₂).
  • • Option A. Complete oxidation of acetyl CoA
  • • Option B. ATP generation - This IS a function of the TCA cycle. The cycle directly generates one GTP (equivalent to one ATP) per turn through substrate-level phosphorylation catalyzed by succinyl-CoA synthetase. More importantly, it indirectly enables substantial ATP production by providing NADH and FADH₂ to the electron transport chain for oxidative phosphorylation.
  • • Option B. ATP generation
  • • Option D. Amphibolic pathway - This IS a characteristic of the TCA cycle. The term "amphibolic" means the pathway serves both catabolic (breakdown) and anabolic (biosynthetic) functions. While the TCA cycle primarily functions in catabolism to generate energy, several of its intermediates serve as precursors for biosynthetic pathways, including:
  • • Option D. Amphibolic pathway
  • • Oxaloacetate and α-ketoglutarate for amino acid synthesis Succinyl-CoA for heme synthesis Citrate for fatty acid synthesis (after transport to the cytosol)
  • • Oxaloacetate and α-ketoglutarate for amino acid synthesis
  • • Succinyl-CoA for heme synthesis
  • • Citrate for fatty acid synthesis (after transport to the cytosol)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Key functions and significance of the TCA cycle include:
  • ➤ Complete oxidation of acetyl-CoA to CO₂ Energy production through substrate-level phosphorylation (GTP) and generation of reducing equivalents (NADH, FADH₂) Serving as a final common oxidative pathway for carbohydrates, proteins, and fats Acting as an amphibolic pathway (both catabolic and anabolic functions)
  • ➤ Complete oxidation of acetyl-CoA to CO₂
  • ➤ Energy production through substrate-level phosphorylation (GTP) and generation of reducing equivalents (NADH, FADH₂)
  • ➤ Serving as a final common oxidative pathway for carbohydrates, proteins, and fats
  • ➤ Acting as an amphibolic pathway (both catabolic and anabolic functions)
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e p161-167.
  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: Considering the physiological adaptations in chronic anemia, assess the following assertion (A) and reasoning (R): Assertion (A): Level of 2,3-BPG is elevated in chronic anaemia. Reasoning (R): High 2,3-BPG levels lowers the oxygen affinity of hemoglobin, permitting unloading of oxygen in tissues.

options.label: A
options.text: A is right but R is a wrong statement

options.label: B
options.text: A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A

options.label: C
options.text: A is wrong but R is a right statement

options.label: D
options.text: A and R both are wrong

questions.correct_answer: B. A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The concentration of 2,3-BPG in the RBC increases in response to chronic hypoxia , such as in COPD like emphysema, or at high altitudes, where circulating haemoglobin may have difficulty receiving sufficient oxygen. Intra cellular levels of 2,3-BPG are also elevated in chronic anaemia, in which fewer than normal RBCs are available to supply the body’s oxygen needs. Elevated 2,3-BPG levels lower the oxygen affinity of haemoglobin , permitting greater unloading of oxygen in the capillaries of the tissues Hb F has low affinity towards 2, 3 BPG.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately reflects a metabolic characteristic of the well-fed state

options.label: A
options.text: NADPH production by the hexose monophosphate shunt is decreased.

options.label: B
options.text: Acetoacetate is the major fuel for muscle.

options.label: C
options.text: Glucose transport into adipose tissue is decreased.

options.label: D
options.text: The major fuel used by the brain is glucose.

questions.correct_answer: D. The major fuel used by the brain is glucose.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)   The major fuel used by the brain is glucose.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. NADPH production by the hexose monophosphate shunt is decreased: Liver production of NADPH is at a high level because it is needed for fatty acid synthesis.
  • • Option A. NADPH production by the hexose monophosphate shunt is decreased:
  • • NADPH
  • • high level
  • • fatty acid synthesis.
  • • Option B. Acetoacetate is the major fuel for muscle: During the absorptive phase , ketone bodies such as acetoacetate and 3-hydroxybutyrate are low with glucose rather than these ketones used by muscle.
  • • Option B. Acetoacetate is the major fuel for muscle:
  • • absorptive phase
  • • ketone bodies
  • • acetoacetate and 3-hydroxybutyrate are low
  • • glucose
  • • Option C. Glucose transport into adipose tissue is decreased: Glucose is actively transported into all cells , including adipocytes, which require it to form glycerol-3-phosphate for esterification of fatty acids into triacylglycerides.
  • • Option C. Glucose transport into adipose tissue is decreased:
  • • Glucose
  • • actively
  • • all cells
  • • adipocytes,
  • • glycerol-3-phosphate
  • • esterification of fatty acids
  • • triacylglycerides.

questions.text: During a pediatric rotation, a medical student observes the management of a child presenting with acute gastroenteritis and signs of dehydration. The attending physician prescribes oral rehydration solution (ORS). The student learns that the efficacy of ORS is partly due to its facilitation of glucose absorption, which in turn enhances electrolyte and water uptake in the intestines. Which glucose transporter is primarily responsible for the glucose absorption facilitated by ORS in the intestinal mucosa?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) SGLT-1

It cotransports sodium and glucose from the intestinal lumen into enterocytes , thereby facilitating the absorption of water and electrolytes, which is the principle behind the effectiveness of ORS.

questions.text: A patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) has been receiving supplemental oxygen therapy for several years, leading to an improvement in symptoms. However, concerns arise regarding potential lung injury from prolonged oxygen exposure, known as oxygen toxicity. This condition can lead to a decrease in the rate of glycolysis due to high oxygen levels. What is the phenomenon called where elevated oxygen levels decrease the glycolysis rate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pasteur Effect.

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Pasteur effect describes the inhibition of glycolysis by high concentrations of oxygen. In the presence of oxygen, cells preferentially utilize aerobic metabolism , which is more efficient in terms of ATP production, leading to a reduced need for glycolysis.

questions.text: In a research project focusing on glucose metabolism, a group of medical students observe that ATP is produced in the cytosol before the breakdown products of glucose enter the mitochondria. questions.explanation:

  • • ATP generation.

questions.text: While conducting a research study on the efficiency of various diets on long-distance runners, a team of exercise physiologists focuses on the metabolic pathways that are most active during extended periods of physical activity. They are particularly interested in quantifying the energy output from different substrates. The team debates the number of ATP molecules generated from the complete oxidation of one molecule of acetyl CoA through the TCA cycle. What is the correct ATP yield from this process?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)  10 ATP

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The oxidation of one molecule of acetyl CoA in the TCA cycle produces 3 NADH, 1 FADH2, and 1 GTP. With the assumption that 1 NADH generates 2.5 ATP and 1 FADH2 yields 1.5 ATP through oxidative phosphorylation, the total ATP produced is calculated as follows:
  • • oxidation of one molecule of acetyl CoA
  • • 3 NADH, 1 FADH2, and 1 GTP.
  • • 1
  • • NADH generates 2.5 ATP
  • • 1 FADH2 yields 1.5 ATP
  • • oxidative phosphorylation,
  • • total ATP
  • • 3 NADH x 2.5 ATP/NADH = 7.5 ATP
  • • 3 NADH x 2.5 ATP/NADH
  • • 7.5 ATP
  • • 1 FADH2 x 1.5 ATP/FADH2 = 1.5 ATP
  • • 1 FADH2 x 1.5 ATP/FADH2 = 1.5 ATP
  • • 1 GTP = 1 ATP
  • • 1 GTP = 1 ATP
  • • The sum of these yields a total of 10 ATP per molecule of acetyl CoA oxidized through the TCA cycle, making option B the most accurate answer.
  • • 10 ATP
  • • acetyl CoA
  • • TCA cycle,
  • • option B
  • • accurate answer.
  • • Note - Three molecules of NADH and one of FADH2 are produced for each molecule of acetyl-CoA catabolized in one turn of the cycle.
  • • Three molecules of NADH
  • • one of FADH2
  • • each molecule of acetyl-CoA
  • • one
  • • cycle.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Ref : Vasudevan 9/e: 253.

questions.text: In conditions of low oxygen levels (low pO2), the body must adapt its metabolic pathways to ensure energy production continues. One such adaptation involves an enzyme that compensates for reduced Tricarboxylic Acid (TCA) cycle activity under hypoxic conditions. This enzyme facilitates a key step in an alternative pathway, allowing cells to generate ATP anaerobically. Which enzyme is responsible for this compensatory mechanism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lactate dehydrogenase

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the malate-aspartate shuttle is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to transport NADH from Cytosol to Mitochondria.

options.label: B
options.text: It is used to transport NADPH from Cytoplasm to Mitochondria.

options.label: C
options.text: Malate get converted to Oxaloacetate and release NADH

options.label: D
options.text: Oxaloacetate is reconstituted from Aspartate and α Ketoglutarate

questions.correct_answer: B. It is used to transport NADPH from Cytoplasm to Mitochondria.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The malate-aspartate shuttle is a key biochemical system that allows the transfer of reducing equivalents (NADH) from the cytosol into the mitochondrial matrix, because the inner mitochondrial membrane is impermeable to NADH itself.
  • • How it works:
  • • How it works:
  • • In the cytosol: Oxaloacetate (OAA) is reduced to malate by cytosolic malate dehydrogenase, using NADH. Malate is transported into the mitochondria. In the mitochondria: Malate is oxidized back to OAA by mitochondrial malate dehydrogenase, regenerating NADH inside the mitochondria. OAA is transaminated to aspartate, which can travel back to the cytosol to complete the cycle.
  • • In the cytosol: Oxaloacetate (OAA) is reduced to malate by cytosolic malate dehydrogenase, using NADH.
  • • Oxaloacetate (OAA) is reduced to malate by cytosolic malate dehydrogenase, using NADH.
  • • Oxaloacetate (OAA) is reduced to malate by cytosolic malate dehydrogenase, using NADH.
  • • Malate is transported into the mitochondria.
  • • In the mitochondria: Malate is oxidized back to OAA by mitochondrial malate dehydrogenase, regenerating NADH inside the mitochondria.
  • • Malate is oxidized back to OAA by mitochondrial malate dehydrogenase, regenerating NADH inside the mitochondria.
  • • Malate is oxidized back to OAA by mitochondrial malate dehydrogenase, regenerating NADH inside the mitochondria.
  • • OAA is transaminated to aspartate, which can travel back to the cytosol to complete the cycle.
  • • Other Option:
  • • Other Option:
  • • Option A. It is used to transport NADH from Cytosol to Mitochondria : True. This is the core purpose of the shuttle. Option B. It is used to transport NADPH from Cytoplasm to Mitochondria : False. The shuttle transports NADH equivalents, not NADPH. NADPH is involved mainly in biosynthesis and antioxidant defenses, not in this shuttle system. Option C. Malate gets converted to Oxaloacetate and releases NADH : True. Inside mitochondria, malate → OAA + NADH (via malate dehydrogenase). Option D. Oxaloacetate is reconstituted from Aspartate and α-Ketoglutarate : True. Aspartate + α-KG ↔ OAA + glutamate (via transamination).
  • • Option A. It is used to transport NADH from Cytosol to Mitochondria : True. This is the core purpose of the shuttle.
  • • Option A. It is used to transport NADH from Cytosol to Mitochondria
  • • Option B. It is used to transport NADPH from Cytoplasm to Mitochondria : False. The shuttle transports NADH equivalents, not NADPH. NADPH is involved mainly in biosynthesis and antioxidant defenses, not in this shuttle system.
  • • Option B. It is used to transport NADPH from Cytoplasm to Mitochondria
  • • Option C. Malate gets converted to Oxaloacetate and releases NADH : True. Inside mitochondria, malate → OAA + NADH (via malate dehydrogenase).
  • • Option C. Malate gets converted to Oxaloacetate and releases NADH
  • • Option D. Oxaloacetate is reconstituted from Aspartate and α-Ketoglutarate : True. Aspartate + α-KG ↔ OAA + glutamate (via transamination).
  • • Option D. Oxaloacetate is reconstituted from Aspartate and α-Ketoglutarate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ The malate-aspartate shuttle transfers cytosolic NADH equivalents into the mitochondria for oxidative phosphorylation . It operates via a series of reversible reactions , involving: Oxaloacetate → Malate (reduced by cytosolic NADH) Malate transport into mitochondria Malate → Oxaloacetate (regenerates NADH in matrix) Transamination of oxaloacetate+ Glutamate ↔ aspartate + α-ketoglutarate
  • ➤ The malate-aspartate shuttle transfers cytosolic NADH equivalents into the mitochondria for oxidative phosphorylation .

  • ➤ cytosolic NADH equivalents

  • ➤ series of reversible reactions
  • ➤ Oxaloacetate → Malate (reduced by cytosolic NADH) Malate transport into mitochondria Malate → Oxaloacetate (regenerates NADH in matrix) Transamination of oxaloacetate+ Glutamate ↔ aspartate + α-ketoglutarate
  • ➤ Oxaloacetate → Malate (reduced by cytosolic NADH)
  • ➤ Oxaloacetate → Malate
